newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Timor Bishop says Clinton supports dialogue.
newsitem.headline: Timor Bishop says Clinton supports dialogue.

text.p: East Timor Bishop Carlos Belo said U.S. President Bill Clinton and U.N. chief Kofi Annan expressed support for planned talks aimed at negotiating a settlement of the territory's problems, Indonesia's official Antara news agency reported on Saturday.

"In principle, U.S. President Bill Clinton and U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan are for a fair, comprehensive and internationally acceptable solution to the East Timor question without armed conflict, which may claim lives and cause material losses," Belo told Antara in Dili, capital of East Timor, on Friday.
Belo could not be reached for comment.

The foreign ministers of Portugal and Indonesia, after an initial two days of U.N.-sponsored meetings, agreed last Friday that senior officials of the two sides would hold intensive talks beginning on July 28.
Belo, who just returned to Indonesia from a two-month peace mission to Europe and the United States, said he also hoped the East Timorese people would support efforts toward a peaceful solution.
"Let us avoid anything which does not support a solution to the East Timor issue while we are trying to solve it in international fora," he said.

The latest discussions between Portuguese Foreign Minister Jaime Gama and his Indonesian counterpart, Ali Alatas, were the ninth in a series that began in 1983 and the first since Annan took office in January.
They are aimed at finding an internationally acceptable solution to the problem of East Timor, which occupies half of the island of Timor in the Indonesian archipelago.
Indonesia occupied East Timor in 1975 after civil war erupted following Portugal's withdrawal from its former colony. Indonesia later annexed the territory.

The territory has been hit recently by the worst upsurge of violence in years, which began when separatists seeking to disrupt Indonesia's May 29 general elections carried out a series of attacks in East Timor. At least 35 people have died in the violence.
On Wednesday, David Alex, a key East Timor rebel believed to have masterminded some of the attacks, died of gunshot wounds after being captured in a gunbattle. He was buried in Dili on Thursday.
